source.c27f2bea:
total_projects_file <- read_excel("../input/total-project-file/Project_file.xlsx")
View (total_projects_file)


activity <- read.csv("../input/fitbit/Fitabase Data 4.12.16-5.12.16/dailyActivity_merged.csv")
sleep <- read.csv("../input/fitbit/Fitabase Data 4.12.16-5.12.16/sleepDay_merged.csv")
heartrate <- read.csv("../input/fitbit/Fitabase Data 4.12.16-5.12.16/heartrate_seconds_merged.csv")
weight <- read.csv("../input/fitbit/Fitabase Data 4.12.16-5.12.16/weightLogInfo_merged.csv")
  

View(activity)
View(sleep)
View(heartrate)
View(weight)

source.e5b0b318:
# Standardized name of variables
activity <- clean_names(activity)
View(activity)
sleep <- clean_names(sleep)
View(sleep)
heartrate <- clean_names(heartrate)
View(heartrate)
weight <- clean_names(weight)
View(weight)
source.37423bcf:
# Reformat date column (from character to date type)
activity <- activity %>%
  mutate(activity_date = as.Date(activity_date, format = "%m/%d/%y")) %>%
  rename(date = activity_date)


sleep <- sleep %>%
  mutate (sleep_day = as.Date(sleep_day, format = "%m/%d/%y")) %>%
  rename(date = sleep_day)

heartrate <- heartrate %>%
  mutate (time = as.Date(time, format = "%m/%d/%y")) %>%
  rename(date = time)

weight <- weight %>%
  mutate (date = as.Date(date, format = "%m/%d/%y"))
source.85561aed:
# Check duplication, missing value
sum(duplicated(activity))
sum(duplicated(sleep))
sum(duplicated(weight))
sum(duplicated(heartrate))

sleep_dup <- sleep %>% filter(duplicated(sleep) == TRUE)
sleep_dup # define the duplication (3)

# Remove duplication of sleep data set
sleep <- unique(sleep)

# Check missing data
sum((is.na(activity) == TRUE))
sum((is.na(sleep) == TRUE))
sum((is.na(heartrate) == TRUE))
sum((is.na(weight) == TRUE))
source.cce7816b:
# Arrange data

activity <- activity %>% 
    arrange(-total_steps)

sleep <- sleep %>%
  arrange (-total_time_in_bed)
source.c0a7a55a:
light_active <- activity %>%
  select(light_active_distance, lightly_active_minutes) %>%
  rename (distance = light_active_distance, time = lightly_active_minutes)
light_active$type <- "light_active"

moderate_active <- activity %>%
  select(moderately_active_distance, fairly_active_minutes) %>%
  rename (distance = moderately_active_distance, time = fairly_active_minutes)
moderate_active$type <- "moderate_active"  


very_active <- activity %>%
  select (very_active_distance, very_active_minutes) %>%
  rename (distance = very_active_distance, time = very_active_minutes)
very_active$type <- "very_active"  

three_level_active <- bind_rows(light_active, moderate_active, very_active)
source.2b15ff0d:
# Visualization 1
ggplot(three_level_active, aes(x = time, y = distance, colour = type))+   
  geom_point() + 
  geom_jitter() +
  geom_smooth(colour = "red", size = 0.25) +
  facet_wrap(~type) +
  labs(title = "Distance and Time comparing in three levels of activity", x = "Time", y = "Level of Activity", caption = "Source data: FitBit Fitness Tracker Data")
source.87456001:
merge_a_s <- merge (activity, sleep, by = c('id', 'date'))
View (merge_a_s)
source.cb603c12:
# Visualization 2
  
attach(merge_a_s)
cor(total_steps, calories)
cor(total_distance, calories)


ggplot(merge_a_s, aes(x = total_distance, y = calories, colour = id))+   
  geom_point() + 
  geom_jitter() +
  geom_smooth(colour = "red", size = 0.25) +
  labs(title = "Total Distance users moving and the amount of burned calories", x = "Total Distance", y = "Calories", caption = "Source data: FitBit Fitness Tracker Data")
source.a39d41d2:
ggplot(merge_a_s, aes(sedentary_minutes, calories)) + 
  geom_point() +
  geom_jitter() +
  geom_smooth(colour = "red", size = 0.25)+
  labs(title = "Sedenary time and Calories Burned per User", x = "Sedenary in Minute", y = "Calories")
source.cf5775b9:
merge_a_s <- merge_a_s %>%
  mutate(not_asleep = total_time_in_bed - total_minutes_asleep)

ggplot(merge_a_s, aes(total_steps, not_asleep, colour = calories)) + 
  geom_point() +
  geom_jitter() +
  geom_smooth(colour = "red", size = 0.25)+
  labs(title = "Total Steps in Day and Time awaked in Bed", x = "Total Steps", y = "Not Asleep")
source.49f863bc:
mean_activity <- activity %>%
  group_by(id) %>%
  summarise(mean_step = mean(total_steps), mean_distance = mean(total_distance), mean_calories = mean (calories))

mean_heartrate <- heartrate %>%
  group_by(id) %>%
  summarise(mean_heartrate_value = mean(value))

mean_weight <- weight %>%
  group_by(id)%>%
  summarise (mean_weight = mean(weight_kg), mean_bmi = mean(bmi))

merge_a_h <- merge(mean_activity, mean_heartrate, by = "id")
merge_a_w <- merge(mean_activity, mean_weight, by = "id")
merge_a_h_w <- merge(merge_a_w, mean_heartrate, bu = "id") 
# We have just one observation existing in all data set (heartrate, weight and activity) that brings almost nonsense for the analysis.
source.cc37c539: The weight and heartrate dataset has only 8 and 7 unique ID in respectively, in comparison to 33 and 24 ID of activity and sleep data set. The data sounds not consistent. I assume this reduction is caused of that users not using all feature. It is necessary to check the consistence among availabe ID across dataset again before merging data.
source.352595eb:
The process has removed 3 duplicated rows in the data set of sleep.
65 missing value has been found in data set of weight. They are all in the Fat column.
source.91085efc:
It is clearly that distance and time active is linearly related to each other. Additionally, we can observe that time of very and moderate active is shorter than light active, but the distance of very active is the longest.


I merge data 2 times. First, since activity and sleep data set has 33 and 24 unique ID,respectively, I will merge 2 data set by ID and date to have an analysis in daily detail. Secondly, since heartrate and weight have just 7,8 unique ID, I will calculate the mean value in activity data set then merge to each data set in turn, in order to able to analysis more features, although the data set seems to be shrinked.
source.a3a31ca2:
# 5. Recommendation 
* Develop a data engineer to collect more consistent, valuable data for a comprehensive analysis.
* Encourage users to engage more in using app.
* Highlight the importance when tracking other features beside daily activity (steps, distance, sleep) such as: heart rate, weight, etc. Simultaneously, adjusting these features for a more easily, simply usage.
source.74134e19:
# Introduction
Bellabeat is a high-tech manufacturer of health-focused products for women, and meet different characters and team members. They are a successful small company, but they have the potential to become a larger player in the global smart device market. 
The company has invested in traditional advertising media, year-round invested in Google Search, maintaining active Facebook and Instagram pages, consistently engages consumers on Twitter, run video ads, etc. Their Chief Creative Officer of Bellabeat believes that analyzing smart device fitness data and available consumer data could help unlock new growth opportunities for the company.
source.e5f1add1: Assume that moving (represented by total steps and total distance) effects the amount of burned calories. I check the correlation of them first. After finding out the correlation between total distance and calories is bigger, I visualize it via plot. The relationship is upward trend meaning that the more distance users moving, the more calories are burned.
source.011a9d54: There is not a clear relationship between sedentary time and calories burned per user. It can be explained that there are many kind of still activities that burn lot of calories (ie.researching, learning, etc.)
source.cc917283:
## Conclusion
* Distance and time active is linearly related to each other. Mostly, users are lightly active in comparison to moderately and very active.
* Moving (represented by distance and time active) is positive correlated to the amount of burned calories per users.
* Sedenary time and the amount of burned calories have no significant relation. 
* Daily active and sleep have no clear relation either.
* People fill the data of daily active and sleep the most, and rarely use the feature measuring heart rate and weight. It is also the reason, I can analyse the relation between daily activity and these feature.
source.6b134e55:
## Metadata
* FitBit Fitness Tracker Data is downloaded from Kaggle data set. 
* These datasets were generated by respondents to a distributed survey via Amazon Mechanical Turk between 03.12.2016-05.12.2016.
* It contains personal fitness tracker from thirty fitbit users. Thirty eligible Fitbit users consented to the submission of personal tracker data, including minute-level output for physical activity, heart rate, and sleep monitoring. It includes information about daily activity, steps, and heart rate that can be used to explore users’ habits. The data set includes 18 CSV files.
source.c6c24a2e: ## Transform data into 3 facets: lightly active, moderate active, and very active
source.5c9d8fe6:
# 1. Ask
## Business task
* Analyze smart device usage data in order to gain insight into how people are already using their smart devices.
* Find the trend to inform Bellabeat marketing strategy

## Characters
* Urška Sršen *: Bellabeat’s cofounder and Chief Creative Officer.  
* Sando Mur *: Mathematician and Bellabeat’s cofounder; key member of the Bellabeat executive team.  
* Bellabeat marketing analytics team *
source.42b20a7c: Data set has 18 csv files which is measured in different unit (daily, hour, minute, second). Some files are structured in wide form, the others are in long form.

source.ceea3b48: I assume that people who are active in day will less awaked time in bed (means that they are easier to fall asleep or get up soon after waking up), but it seems not true. However, at least, some out-liers of not asleep are user who have less steps (under 5000). And users who spend long time awaked in bed also have less amount of calories burned in day.
